Opportunities http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk Opportunities within the Department of Oncology daily 1 2012-08-07T12:32:19Z Postdoctoral Researcher in Cancer Virotherapy and Immunotherapy (2 posts) http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/d9fa3ea2a4306837a799fa3163c3b87b An excellent opportunity has arisen for two postdoctoral researchers to join the Department of Oncology. The posts are within Professor Seymour\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research group, which has a longstanding interest in using viruses as cancer therapies. The primary focus of the appointees will be to design and engineer lytic viruses with improved anticancer properties. An excellent opportunity has arisen for two postdoctoral researchers to join the Department of Oncology. The posts are within Professor Seymour’s research group, which has a longstanding interest in using viruses as cancer therapies. The primary focus of the appointees will be to design and engineer lytic viruses with improved anticancer properties. Major areas of focus will be in understanding mechanisms of cell killing, how oncolytic viruses behave in the cancer microenvironment, and how they can engender a strong anticancer immune response.

You will have a PhD in virology, immunology, biotechnology or molecular or cell biology, along with significant experience in molecular virology and/or immunological research. You will have extensive experience of molecular engineering and/or immunological techniques, along with experience with lytic viruses and tissue culture. You will have a publication record of primary scientific papers, as well as a proven track record of successful grant writing.

These are full-time posts and are fixed-term until 30 September 2019.

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Wednesday 25 March 2015. ]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-02-17T17:20:05Z Feed Item Postdoctoral Researcher - Oncology http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/630bd5aab5a7dd729c2b3ebad7562fe6 We have an opportunity for a Postdoctoral Researcher to join the Department of Oncology Preclinical Validation Laboratory. You will design, execute and interpret in vivo anti-tumour efficacy studies. Using a range of techniques, including immunohistochemistry and FACS, you will help to identify and evaluate potential novel biomarkers. We have an opportunity for a Postdoctoral Researcher to join the Department of Oncology Preclinical Validation Laboratory. You will design, execute and interpret in vivo anti-tumour efficacy studies. Using a range of techniques, including immunohistochemistry and FACS, you will help to identify and evaluate potential novel biomarkers. This post will give you the opportunity to work with diverse preclinical model systems and with a wide range of therapeutic approaches and biological mechanisms.

You will have a PhD or equivalent in a cancer-related research area. You will also have recent practical experience of working with in vivo models of cancer and a current UK Home Office Personal Licence (PIL). Expertise in mammalian cell tissue culture techniques and in immunohistochemistry of human tumours are also essential. Evidence of first author publications in peer-reviewed scientific journals would be advantageous.

This is a full-time post fixed-term and available until 31 March 2017.

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 25 March 2015.
]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-03-18T11:59:38Z Feed Item Hyperpolarized Xe MRI Postdoctoral Researcher http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/ab8fe9652599795f376f9b1a39a605db We are looking for a Hyperpolarized Xe MRI Postdoctoral Researcher to join the Functional Imaging and Radiotherapy Physics group headed by Dr Mike Partridge. You will provide physics support for clinical trials involving hyperpolarized xenon MRI. In collaboration with the Oxford Cancer Centre, the necessary hardware has been acquired and commissioned and exciting clinical trials of this relatively rare technique are already in progress. We are looking for a Hyperpolarized Xe MRI Postdoctoral Researcher to join the Functional Imaging and Radiotherapy Physics group headed by Dr Mike Partridge. You will provide physics support for clinical trials involving hyperpolarized xenon MRI. In collaboration with the Oxford Cancer Centre, the necessary hardware has been acquired and commissioned and exciting clinical trials of this relatively rare technique are already in progress. In addition to data acquisition and processing for trials in progress, you will continue to develop, implement and optimize imaging sequences and clinical protocols.

You will have a PhD in physics, medical imaging or a related subject and relevant experience in MRI. You will also have experience of successfully preparing and submitting scientific data for publication. The ability to work independently and using initiative is essential.

This is a full-time post and is fixed-term for 3 years (or to 30 November 2018, whichever is sooner).

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Wednesday 1 April 2015. ]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-02-24T12:07:58Z Feed Item Postdoctoral Researcher in Targeted Drug Delivery to Brain Tumours http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/fc142646e4f27228822f78c512abcf65 We are seeking a Postdoctoral Researcher in Targeted Drug Delivery to Brain Tumours to join the Department of Oncology. You will join the Experimental Neuroimaging Group, a dynamic group with interests spanning many aspects of brain cancer, neuroinflammation and neuroimaging. You will become part of the new cross-departmental EPSRC-funded Oxford Centre for Drug Delivery Devices in which we aim to combine biological and magnetic targeting of microparticles for simultaneous detection of, and ... We are seeking a Postdoctoral Researcher in Targeted Drug Delivery to Brain Tumours to join the Department of Oncology. You will join the Experimental Neuroimaging Group, a dynamic group with interests spanning many aspects of brain cancer, neuroinflammation and neuroimaging. You will become part of the new cross-departmental EPSRC-funded Oxford Centre for Drug Delivery Devices in which we aim to combine biological and magnetic targeting of microparticles for simultaneous detection of, and therapy delivery to, micrometastatic tumour colonies in the brain.

The primary aim of this post will be to use both imaging and immunohistochemical approaches to demonstrate accumulation of microparticles at sites of brain metastases and effective ultrasound-mediated therapy delivery. Supporting in vitro experiments will be conducted to test all promising constructs prior to in vivo application.

You will have a PhD in cancer biology, neuroscience, inflammation or related subject. You will have experience with in vivo experimental models, preferably cancer or neuroscience-based, as well as experience with in vivo magnetic resonance imaging. You will also need technical competence in standard immunohistochemical, immunofluorescence and molecular biology techniques.

This is a full-time post and is fixed-term for 2 years.

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on Thursday 2 April 2015. ]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-02-24T12:07:59Z Feed Item Research Assistant - Oncology http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/26661f66c14b1db27d01efbc40b97a9d We are currently seeking a Research Assistant to join Dr Val Macaulay\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds team working with scientists at the Oxford Cancer Research Centre. The role will include performing in vitro drug testing as part of an initiative to support preclinical evaluation of novel concepts in cancer therapy, in order to strengthen the scientific rationale for clinical studies. We are currently seeking a Research Assistant to join Dr Val Macaulay’s team working with scientists at the Oxford Cancer Research Centre. The role will include performing in vitro drug testing as part of an initiative to support preclinical evaluation of novel concepts in cancer therapy, in order to strengthen the scientific rationale for clinical studies.

It is anticipated that data from this work will provide the scientific underpinning to accelerate clinical testing, both within Oxford and more widely, and it is expected that the majority of the data generated will be published in international peer-reviewed journals.

We are looking for an enthusiastic and organised bench-worker with a BSc in molecular biology, biochemistry, biology or a related science. You will have a high level of technical competence in cell biology methods, the ability to design robust experiments and critically interpret data, and to communicate effectively both orally and in writing. It will be advantageous to possess a postgraduate research qualification (MSc or MRes) and to have experience in cancer research.

This is a full-time post fixed-term for 2 years in the first instance.

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 2 April 2015.
]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-03-02T10:57:59Z Feed Item Biostatistician/Statistical Scientist in Oncology http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/5932096b6e2ae8f0188e25e8d5f66c1d We have an exciting opportunity for a Biostatistician to contribute to and help lead on the analysis of large-scale data sets in molecular oncology. The purpose of the role is to provide Biostatistical expertise to the Core and contribute to the design of studies, the analysis of data and the development of new analytical methods. We have an exciting opportunity for a Biostatistician to contribute to and help lead on the analysis of large-scale data sets in molecular oncology. The purpose of the role is to provide Biostatistical expertise to the Core and contribute to the design of studies, the analysis of data and the development of new analytical methods. The person appointed will be interacting directly with researchers to help identify project funding opportunities, to maintain the scientific quality and integrity of projects and ensure their timely completion. You will focus on statistical analyses of cancer data sets assessing clinical/phenotypic data, genomics and other *omics biomarkers for association with the risk of disease and its progression.

The successful applicant will have an MSc or PhD in statistics or related discipline or equivalent. Strong quantitative skills, including experience in analysing large-scale and high dimensional data (e.g. genomics, epigenomics, metabolomics, array-based technologies) using relevant software (e.g. R) are essential. You should also possess the ability to organise and prioritise your own work, as well as have excellent communication skills, both written and oral. The post will involve interactions with collaborators from such diverse fields as applied mathematics, statistics, computer science and medicine.

This is a full-time post and is available until 31 March 2017 in the first instance.

A lower grade post may be offered (Grade 6: £27,057 - £32,277 p.a.) with a commensurate reduction in responsibilities if a suitable candidate cannot be found to fill the Grade 7 position.

For informal enquiries, contact Dr Anastasia Samsonova (bioinformatics@oncology.ox.ac.uk).

All applicants must complete an application form and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 2 April 2015. ]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-03-02T10:58:00Z Feed Item Clinical Trial Administrator http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/a479a648e982269a2039603cb5eb47ec An exciting opportunity has become available for a Clinical Trial Administrator based in the Oncology Clinical Trials Office (OCTO), which forms part of the Department of Oncology and is also the oncology division of the UKCRC registered clinical trials unit, OCTRU (Oxford Clinical Trials Research Unit). An exciting opportunity has become available for a Clinical Trial Administrator based in the Oncology Clinical Trials Office (OCTO), which forms part of the Department of Oncology and is also the oncology division of the UKCRC registered clinical trials unit, OCTRU (Oxford Clinical Trials Research Unit). OCTO has good working relationships with UK-wide study sites and international groups in Europe.

OCTO runs academic clinical trials to the highest standards and is proactive in improving clinical trial procedures and delivering high quality data.

You will provide support to a team of trial management professionals and will be involved in many aspects of clinical trial administration, such as performing site accreditation calls, corresponding with the regulatory bodies and R&D departments, handling clinical queries and organising trial meetings. Occasional travel will be required as part of this role.

You will be educated to A-level or equivalent in a biomedical or associated subject. You will have effective communication and inter-personal skills, as well as critical and intelligent attention to detail and high standards of accuracy. You will also have had experience of working to Good Clinical Practice guidelines and experience of UK clinical research structures, regulatory and ethical systems.

This is a full-time post and is fixed-term for 2 years in the first instance.

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 10 April 2015. ]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-03-18T11:59:39Z Feed Item Clinical Trial Coordinator http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/8a2eebaa4436e5879a224f33bff25d83 We are looking for an experienced Clinical Trial Coordinator to join the Oncology Clinical Trials Office of trial management professionals, running a wide portfolio of early phase and late phase clinical trials, and related sub-studies. The trials work across different tumour types and therapeutic areas and are at varying stages. We are looking for an experienced Clinical Trial Coordinator to join the Oncology Clinical Trials Office of trial management professionals, running a wide portfolio of early phase and late phase clinical trials, and related sub-studies. The trials work across different tumour types and therapeutic areas and are at varying stages.

You will be responsible for a range of activities including defining study specific procedures, setting up and managing study sites, promoting and monitoring recruitment of subjects, preparing regulatory and ethical submissions, preparing and presenting progress reports, data collection, assisting with analysis and publication of trials.

You should have a degree, or other relevant qualification, in a biomedical or associated subject and demonstrable experience in clinical trial management including understanding of clinical research methodology and good clinical practice. You will need good administrative and project management skills with the ability to work on your own initiative, problem solve and organise the work of a professional team under management guidance.

Whilst the role is a Grade 7 position, we would be willing to consider candidates with potential but less experience who are seeking a development opportunity, for which an initial appointment would be at Grade 6 (£26,527 - £31,644 p.a.) with the responsibilities adjusted accordingly. This would be discussed with applicants at interview/appointment where appropriate.

This is a full-time post and is offered for a fixed-term of 2 years in the first instance.

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 22 April 2014. ]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-03-18T11:59:39Z Feed Item Research Assistant - Histopathology http://www.oncology.ox.ac.uk/opportunities/c92caf29b9d5fa5b72dbed32178bc4b7 An exciting opportunity has arisen for a Research Assistant, who is especially familiar with histopathology, to work on problems in cancer biology involving metastasis and radiation therapy. This work is part of a collaborative project with biotechnology company, Galaxy Biotech. You will provide histopathology expertise and support to students and scientists in the laboratory of Professor Ruth Muschel within the Oxford Institute for Radiation Oncology. An exciting opportunity has arisen for a Research Assistant, who is especially familiar with histopathology, to work on problems in cancer biology involving metastasis and radiation therapy. This work is part of a collaborative project with biotechnology company, Galaxy Biotech.

You will provide histopathology expertise and support to students and scientists in the laboratory of Professor Ruth Muschel within the Oxford Institute for Radiation Oncology. This new role will be investigating, using mainly immunohistochemistry, the nature of infiltrating cells in cancers and some of the proteins that they deposit in the extracellular matrix.

You will have proven experience in preclinical and/or clinical histopathology laboratory tissue handling and processing techniques including using fresh, frozen and paraffin embedded cells and/or tissue specimens. You will also have proven experience of histopathological and immunohistochemical staining (chromogenic and fluorescence) techniques, including data interpretation and analysis skills. Strong organisational skills for planning and delivery high quality experimental work are also essential.

This is a full-time post and is fixed-term and available for 1 year in the first instance.

All applicants must complete a short application form and upload a CV and supporting statement.

To apply for this role, please click on the ‘Apply Now’ button in the link below.

The closing date for applications is 12.00 noon on 24 April 2015. ]]> No publisher Paul Hodges 2015-03-19T15:51:25Z Feed Item
